Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild directly asks their grandfather for help and advice with a serious concern in their life.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: Tonight, as the sun dipped below the horizon, my grandson came to me, his eyes clouded with worry. “Grandpa, can we talk? I really need your advice,” he said, his voice trembling. I could see he was carrying a heavy burden, and my heart ached to be the guiding hand he needed. Yet, tonight was also the community Quran study circle—a gathering I had committed to, where we would discuss verses I hadn’t yet read or reflected upon. As a Muslim, I felt the weight of my responsibility to honor the Quran, to be prepared and present with my brothers and sisters in faith. My mind raced, torn between the duty to my family and the duty to my faith. I wanted to give my grandson my full attention, to share my wisdom and comfort him, but I also felt the pull of my spiritual obligations, the expectation to be a devoted member of my community. The clock ticked on, and I sat in silence, wrestling with the impossible choice before me.
